persona.name: María Concepción Téllez Zapata

occupation.title: Retired smallholder farmer and former community health promoter (promotora de salud)
occupation.description: Until retirement from active daily fieldwork, María combined subsistence agriculture (small milpa for maize, beans and squash), a few goats and chickens, and informal caregiving. For approximately 15 years she served as a local promotora: helping nurses from the distant rural clinic with childhood vaccination days, giving basic health education (hygiene, nutrition, recognizing danger signs in pregnancy), and assisting women during births as a traditional midwife when needed. She is not formally employed and is considered 'not in the labor force' now — she continues occasional piecework (weeding or shelling maize for neighbors for small payments), looks after grandchildren, manages household finances, and organizes food for communal events. Responsibilities she handled included: organizing community vaccination notices; leading a rota for water-and-firewood collection; treating minor ailments with herbal remedies; preparing and mashing tortillas; negotiating small sales of surplus maize or eggs at the nearby town market; and mentoring younger women in sewing and caring for babies.

persona.residence: Small village near Tlaxiaco, Mixteca region, Oaxaca (rural household)
persona.education: Attended local primary school until 4th grade (left early to help in the milpa and care for younger siblings). Later participated in sporadic adult-literacy workshops and a short community health promoter training (promotora) run by a regional NGO in the 1990s. Can read simple Spanish texts (letters, notices) slowly; writes her name and simple numbers. Fluent in Mixtec (local variant) and conversational Spanish with rural pronunciation.
long_term_goals: See her youngest grandchildren finish at least primary school and be able to read and write well in Spanish.
Keep the small plot of milpa productive and pass on the traditional seed of maize to the next generation.
Remain in her village with enough health care and the monthly government pension to cover medicines and basic food.
Attend the next patron-saint fiesta and see the next procession organized by her goddaughter.
Teach a younger neighbor the medicinal uses of at least ten local plants.
Have a small solar lamp and reliable radio/TV so she can follow the news and listen to Mass if she cannot go to church.
Keep family ties strong so that children who migrated continue to visit or send remittances.
Die at home in the village, surrounded by family, with a funeral paid for without causing financial strain on her children.
persona.style: Soft-spoken but direct. Speaks primarily in Mixtec at home and uses Spanish when dealing with officials or when visiting the municipal seat. Her Spanish carries a southern rural accent with occasional use of local idioms and proverbs; she often adds diminutives like "-ito/-ita" when speaking to children or clients (e.g., "mi chiquita"). Uses polite formal address ('usted') with outsiders and younger, more intimate terms ('m'ija', 'm'ijo') with relatives. Walks steadily but deliberately, carrying a woven rebozo over her shoulder which she uses as a sling for infants or to carry market goods. In conversation she pauses to choose words, repeats key points, and often tells short anecdotes to make a point. Likes to hum ranchera songs and occasionally breaks into a simple prayer or a short blessing before meals. Mannerisms: smoothes the hem of her huipil when nervous, taps a wooden pestle handle when thinking, frequently touches her forehead in moments of sadness or remembrance. Dress is traditional: embroidered blouse/huipil, ankle-length skirt, worn sandals, and a well-used rebozo. In town she may put on a simple cardigan. Technology use is minimal — a basic feature phone for calls and occasional WhatsApp messages from children; prefers listening to the radio or watching telenovelas and news on the shared TV at her daughter's house.

traits: Deeply relational: places family and community ties at the center of decisions.
Practical and resourceful: finds ways to mend tools, reuse materials and solve everyday problems.
Resilient: has endured hardships (crop failures, bereavement) yet remains active in the community.
Cautiously optimistic: hopes for small improvements but does not expect miracles.
Distrustful of distant officials: skeptical of promises from municipal leaders and formal institutions.
Warm and nurturing: enjoys caring for grandchildren and neighbors.
Modest pride: values dignity and independence, dislikes being treated as helpless.
Superstitious in a cultural way: combines Catholic belief with respect for traditional rituals and local healers.
Conservative about gender roles but pragmatic: expects men and women to share some burdens but holds to traditional divisions in certain tasks.
Patient storyteller: often uses stories to teach, admonish, or comfort.
Low tolerance for waste and extravagance: prefers saving and careful spending.
Strong sense of justice within customary law: believes in community assemblies to settle disputes.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness moderate-low: values tradition and practical knowledge but is curious about grandchildren's stories from the city. Conscientiousness above average: reliable, keeps schedules for household and communal duties. Extraversion moderate: enjoys company at church and market, but also values quiet time. Agreeableness high: cooperative and helpful, though firm when defending family. Neuroticism somewhat low: generally calm but experiences bouts of sadness tied to loss and worry about money.

interests: Maintaining the milpa and exchanging seeds with neighboring families.
Cooking traditional dishes from scratch: nixtamalizing maize, preparing tamales, mole for fiestas.
Attending Mass at the village church on Sundays and fiestas patronales several times a year.
Listening to ranchera, bolero and older Mexican ballads on the radio while grinding nixtamal.
Watching specific telenovelas in the afternoon at a neighbor's house and following national news broadcasts.
Participating in the community 'tequio' (collective labor) for road repairs or fiesta preparations.
Weaving simple items and mending huipiles and rebozos; embroidering panels for family garments.
Tending a small kitchen garden: cilantro, onion, nopal, chilies, and medicinal herbs like epazote.
Collecting and preparing herbal remedies for stomach aches, coughs and wounds.
Bargaining at the municipal market once a week for sugar, salt and soap.
Listening to the radio priest on Wednesdays or a health program when available.
Seeing her children and grandchildren during school holidays and family events.
Receiving remittances and deciding together with children how to spend the money (home repairs, medicine, food).
Keeping the house clean and orderly; she values a swept courtyard and stored firewood.
Participating in local women's groups that meet to sew, pray, and gossip — she enjoys the social contact.
Prefers face-to-face interactions; phone calls are functional but impersonal.
Prefers buying staples from the local tienda where she knows the owner and can get informal credit.
Enjoys telling stories to grandchildren about the old days and local legends.
Likes simple treats: panela (piloncillo), sweet corn at harvest, café de olla with cinnamon.
Values quiet nights with the family around a small wood fire, listening to the wind and the radio.
likes: Warm tortillas made on a comal straight from the nixtamal process.
The smell of fresh rain on the milpa.
Seeing children in school uniforms and hearing their reading aloud.
Small, steady amounts of remittance that cover medicine and a sack of maize.
When the local clinic's nurse arrives on schedule for vaccination day.
Local festivals: the procession, the fireworks, the tamales distributed afterwards.
Her old rebozo, which has both practical and sentimental value.
A well-cooked pot of beans that feeds many mouths.
Neighbourly exchanges: swapping eggs for green salsa or lending a sack of maize seed.
Being consulted on family matters and community assemblies.
When her godchildren call to ask for advice, showing they still respect her.
Having a small savings tin at home to stash coins for emergencies.
The quiet hours early in the morning when the village is cool and birds sing.
Candles and small offerings for the dead during Día de Muertos; it connects her to ancestors.
Simple handicrafts she can finish in the evenings while talking.
A radio with clear reception and a neighbor willing to share television time.
The taste of pozole or atole during cold weather.
Walking to church with neighbors and singing during the procession.
When municipal aid (food packages or pension payments) actually arrives and is complete.
Seeing a neighbor's baby thrive after she gave breastfeeding or herbal advice.
dislikes: Corrupt or lazy municipal officials who promise repairs and do not show up.
When remittances arrive late or are smaller than expected.
Long waits at the clinic when the nurse doesn't have medicine or leaves early.
Youths who disrespect elders or abandon traditional responsibilities in the milpa.
Loud, reckless behavior during religious observances.
Expensive goods with little use; dislikes wasting money on flashy items.
Being treated as an unknowable 'beneficiary' rather than a community member with knowledge.
Heavy rains that wash away small terraces or newly planted maize.
Fake medicines sold by pushy traders; prefers known remedies.
Having to travel long distances to the municipal seat for paperwork.
When grandchildren prefer screen time to helping with household chores.
Hospitals that separate families from patients and charge unpredictable fees.
Foreign (to her) foods that her grandchildren are pressured to accept without explanation.
Gossip that unfairly damages reputations — she prefers measured discussion in assemblies.
When the road is blocked and the truck carrying market goods cannot pass.
Being teased about not having formal education — she values knowledge gained through experience.
Television channels that constantly show violence or debauchery.
Sudden changes in market prices that make staple foods unaffordable.
Excessive questioning by officials in Spanish when she only understands Mixtec nuance.
When helpers come and leave without learning to respect local customs.
entertainment_preferences: Radio novela episodes in the morning while preparing food.
Telenovelas in the afternoon when visiting her daughter; she follows a few characters' arcs and discusses them with neighbors.
Local religious broadcasts of Mass when weather prevents travel to church.
Occasional trips to the town fair with music and dance; prefers slower ranchera songs.
Singing boleros softly while shelling beans or weaving in the evening.
Listening to government announcements on the radio about health campaigns or pension payments.
media_and_tech: Owns a simple feature phone used mostly for voice calls and occasional WhatsApp voice messages from children in the city and abroad.
Shares a small battery-powered radio with neighbors; tuned to AM community or national news and music stations.
Uses a neighbor's television to watch central news and telenovelas; prefers programs on Televisa/TV Azteca that include news summaries.
Does not use social media herself but knows that grandchildren use Facebook and WhatsApp to send photos and updates.
Saves battery by charging the phone at her daughter's house or occasionally at a tienda with a small fee.

beliefs: Health is a combination of God's will and practical care; you must both pray and use remedies.
The government should provide pensions and basic healthcare to older people — programs like the elder pension are essential.
Public hospitals are useful but distant and often disrespectful to rural life; local clinics and promotoras are vital.
Traditional medicine (herbs, steam baths, massage) has value and should be respected alongside clinic medicine.
Children should learn both Spanish and the indigenous language; language loss is a real sadness.
Land and seeds inherited from ancestors are sacred; selling the ancestral milpa is a last resort.
Migration is painful but sometimes necessary — if a child goes north to earn money, they still owe obligations to the family.
Corruption at the municipal level steals resources that should help the community.
Political promises are often empty unless there are visible, repeated actions.
Social programs (pensions, Prospera historically, now Pensión para el Bienestar) have improved the lives of many elders and are worth supporting.
Morena's emphasis on social programs feels close to the needs of her community; she voted for party candidates who promised pensions.
Voting is important because occasionally a leader will deliver services; but low trust remains because of repeated betrayals.
The Church is a center of moral life; priests can be helpful but sometimes distant from rural concerns.
Festivals and saints' days maintain social cohesion and spiritual balance; they must be observed properly.
Young people should show respect for elders, but they also deserve opportunities (education, decent work) so they do not have to migrate.
Education is important but cannot replace lived knowledge about farming and household management.
Markets should be fair; middlemen who take advantage of small producers are a problem.
Community assemblies and customary law are legitimate ways to resolve small conflicts; external courts are slow and alien.
Money is useful but it cannot replace family; sending a remittance is both a duty and a sign of love.
Women carry a double burden (household and field) and deserve respect and recognition for unpaid labor.
Elders are repositories of memory and should be consulted about major communal decisions.
Government healthcare expansion is necessary; fear that small clinics will be closed due to budget cuts worries her.
Environmental changes (less regular rains, hotter seasons) are visible and threaten the milpa; this worries her deeply.
Traditional male migration patterns have changed family dynamics — more women manage households and land now.
She believes that community leaders should be chosen for service, not for favors or cash.
Private clinics sometimes extract money but do not guarantee better care than the public clinic.
Remittances help families but create dependency risks if younger generations stop producing locally.
Education that forces children to leave the community for long is a mixed blessing: it provides opportunity but erodes local life.
Public investment in local roads, potable water and clinic staffing would transform everyday realities.
Being polite and humble opens doors; arrogance closes them, especially in dealings with neighbors and authorities.
She values persons who keep their word — a promise fulfilled matters more than a speech.
Better access to pensions and medical care reduces migration pressures by allowing elders to remain cared for at home.
skills: Experienced milpa management: planting, weeding, timing sowing to late rains, saving heirloom seeds.
Nixtamalization and masa preparation to make tortillas, tamales and atoles.
Basic primary maternal care and traditional midwifery skills: assisting births, recognizing danger signs, referring to clinic when necessary.
Herbal medicine knowledge: preparing infusions of chamomile, epazote, hierba buena, eucalyptus steam for colds, and poultices for bruises.
Household budgeting and informal savings: knows how to stretch small monthly pensions and remittances.
Weaving and embroidery: repairing huipiles, making simple woven bags and rebozos.
Basic numeracy for market bargaining and record-keeping of small loans.
Negotiation skills with tienda owners for informal credit and delayed payments.
Community organizing: coordinating tequios, calling neighbors for fiesta preparation and vaccination days.
Caregiving skills for infants and elderly: feeding, bathing, administering medicines.
Simple tool repair: sharpening machetes, fixing wooden handles, patching clay pots.
Oral storytelling and teaching: passing on local proverbs, songs and agricultural knowledge.
Simple use of a feature phone: answering calls, sending/receiving voice messages, recognizing contacts.
Basic Spanish to interact with municipal offices, health staff, and market vendors.
Emotional labor: mediating family disputes, comforting those in grief.

general: Greets everyone in the courtyard and checks who needs help before breakfast.
Prays a short morning prayer and blesses the food before eating.
Uses a daily tin to stash small coins, counting at the end of the week to see if there's enough for sugar or medicine.
Keeps a small herb garden near the door and harvests leaves daily for tea or cooking.
Takes part in community assemblies and voices opinions in a calm but firm way.
When remittances arrive she discusses allocation decisions with her children and sometimes insists on investing in the house roof or a small stove.
Prefers to pay debts early to maintain good standing with local shopkeepers.
Hums while working; chants short prayers at crossroads or before threshing grain.
Avoids going to large hospitals unless necessary because of distance and costs.
Keeps one corner of the house tidy with pictures of deceased relatives and candles during holidays.

morning: Wakes around 5:30–6:00 AM when it's still cool.
Lights the small wood-burning stove, prepares nixtamal or heats water for coffee (café de olla).
Feeds chickens and goats, collects eggs, checks the courtyard and kitchen garden.
Prepares tortillas and a simple breakfast (warm tortilla and beans or atole) for family and grandchildren.
Prays a short rosary depending on the day and the liturgical calendar.
workday: Spends two to three hours in the milpa/weeding or helping tend crops if weather permits; otherwise does household chores: washing, mending, cooking large pots.
Stops mid-morning to rest and share news with neighbors; often exchanges news about who visited the clinic.
After midday she may go to a neighbor's house to watch a TV news segment or a telenovela episode and exchange gossip.
If it's market day, walks (or takes a shared truck) to the municipal market with a small load to trade or buy staples.
May host or attend a community meeting in the afternoon for planning or fiesta preparation.
evening: Prepares dinner (often a simple stew) and eats with family.
Sits outside on milpa side or internal patio, mends clothing, and tells stories or sings softly to grandchildren before bed.
Lights a candle on the small family altar when worried or before important decisions.
Goes to bed early, around 9:00–10:00 PM, especially in colder months.
weekend: Participates actively in Sunday Mass and socializes afterwards during the plaza's gathering.
Helps organize or attends fiestas and wakes when relatives die; these are large communal obligations.
Visits neighbors who are ill to bring food or medicines.
When there is a special event (wedding, baptism), spends the weekend preparing large amounts of food and coordinating contributions.

physical.general_state: Fragile but functional. Able to walk short distances, carry light loads, and perform most household tasks with occasional help.
chronic_conditions: Hypertension (diagnosed 8 years ago) — takes a generic antihypertensive irregularly when money allows.
Osteoarthritis in knees and lower back — causes stiffness, worse in the rainy season.
Reduced visual acuity consistent with cataracts and age-related refractive error; has trouble reading small text.
Partial hearing loss especially for high frequencies; relies on repetition in conversation.
Dental problems: several missing teeth, occasional toothaches.
medications_and_care: Occasional antihypertensive tablets supplied by the rural clinic; sometimes runs out and uses herbal teas as comfort.
Uses topical salves and poultices for joint pain (arnica-like preparations, eucalyptus steam).
Receives yearly influenza and tetanus vaccines when the clinic team visits.
Has not had cataract surgery due to distance/cost but hopes for a campaign that offers it.
Attends clinic vaccination days for grandchildren and goes with them for measurements and growth checks.
physical.mobility: Can walk about 2–3 kilometers but prefers shorter trips and uses a simple wooden walking stick during wet or cold stretches.
physical.nutrition: Diet based on maize, beans, squash, occasional chicken or goat meat; eats seasonal vegetables and some store-bought sugar and oil. Low protein intake some months of the year. Suffers occasional food insecurity late in the planting cycle.
physical.mental_health: Mostly stable mood with moments of sadness linked to the death of her husband 10 years ago and worries about finances and grandchildren. Mild, intermittent anxiety about health and money; finds relief through prayer, social contact and storytelling.

access_to_healthcare.primary_care: Uses the nearest community clinic (rural health unit) when the nurse is present; trusts local promotoras for triage and early referral.
access_to_healthcare.specialist_care: Rarely accesses specialists due to distance, transport cost and paperwork. Trips to the municipal hospital happen only for severe conditions or referrals.
access_to_healthcare.insurance: Enrolled in the national program for people without employment-based insurance (previously Seguro Popular, now attends services under IMSS-Bienestar/INSABI-driven outreach when available).

relationships.name: José Téllez (deceased)
relationships.relation: Husband (died 10 years ago after a work-related accident in the milpa and complications)
relationships.description: Married for 48 years. Their union was steady, he assisted in fieldwork and small construction; his death made Maria Concepción take a more visible communal role. She still mourns him and lights candles on his birthday.

relationships.name: María Elena (Elena) Téllez (49)
relationships.relation: Eldest daughter, lives in the same village
relationships.description: Helps manage household chores, watches grandchildren when María Concepción needs rest, travels with her to the municipal market and shares remittance money decisions. Works occasionally as a domestic helper in nearby town.

relationships.name: Guadalupe (Lupita) Téllez (45)
relationships.description: Migrated to the city some years ago for work in a sewing cooperative; sends small remittances and calls regularly. Provides advice on schooling for grandchildren.

relationships.name: Carlos Téllez (50)
relationships.relation: Son, living in the United States (California)
relationships.description: Migrated two decades ago, sends monthly remittances which financed a roof repair and helps with medicine costs. Visits rarely but calls for important events. Political views more open to urban ideas, but respects his mother's traditions.

relationships.name: Five grandchildren (ages 2–16)
relationships.description: She cares for the youngest grandchildren regularly; older ones attend secondary school in the municipal seat. Proud when they earn good grades and worries about those who think about migrating.

relationships.name: Doña Rosa
relationships.description: Close friend who exchanged seeds and labor for decades; they support each other in sickness and attend Mass together.

relationships.name: Local nurse (Nurse Patricia)
relationships.description: Works at the rural clinic; coordinated vaccination days with María Concepción when she was a promotora. They share a respectful, collaborative relationship.

relationships.name: Parish priest (Father Ángel)
relationships.description: Respected spiritual leader; sometimes helps mediate community disputes and organizes confessions and Masses during fiestas.

relationships.name: Several godchildren and compadrazgo network
relationships.description: Strong reciprocal ties — she is godmother to children of neighbors and in return receives help and support in times of need.

relationships.name: Neighbors and women's group
relationships.description: Informal support network for childcare, emergency loans, and collective work. They rotate duties for fiesta food and cleaning.

other_facts: Born in the village in the early 1950s; one of eight children in a subsistence farming household.
Left school early to help with the milpa and to look after younger siblings when her mother was ill.
Married at age 18 in a largely arranged match with José; together they maintained a two-hectare plot of communal-style milpa and raised goats.
Delivered her first child at home with the help of an older midwife; later she assisted dozens of births in the community herself.
Has a strong memory for dates and family events; she remembers who loaned seed during a drought 30 years ago and repaid them later.

Once organized a small protest at the municipal seat to demand that the road be repaired after a season of floods; the protest forced the mayor to come and promise action (which was only partially fulfilled).
Her husband died in a farming accident when a temporary structure collapsed; the funeral left a lasting financial strain and marked a turning point in her life.
Received a small monthly pension from a national program (Pensión para el Bienestar) which made paying for medicine and occasional food staples possible.
Participated in a government-sponsored adult education class in the 1990s where she improved her Spanish reading a little and met other women who became lifelong friends.
Has a small altar in the kitchen with photos of deceased relatives, candles and a small jar of salt used in offerings.
Knows at least a dozen medicinal plants by name in Mixtec and Spanish and where they grow near seasonal creeks and terraces.
Is sometimes critical of NGOs that hold one-off workshops and then leave; prefers steady, long-term programs that build local capacity.
Was the community promotoras' informal coordinator for a few years, organizing vaccination days and maternal care referrals.
Remembers the name and features of the first teacher who taught her to write her name — she mentions him by name to her grandchildren as an example of patience.
Has a wooden mortar (metate) and stone grinding stone passed down through the family, still used for special preparations like pinole or masa for tamales at fiestas.
Values a simple annual ritual where the family cleans the graves of ancestors and prepares favorite foods for their memory.
Once used a remittance to buy a small stacked brick oven (hornito) that made cooking more efficient and reduced smoke in the house.
Keeps small paper records of debts and loans in a folded envelope in the kitchen drawer.
Is pragmatic about technology: appreciates the phone for hearing her son's voice from California but distrusts the internet's rumors.
Knows the name of the municipal president and is skeptical after multiple broken promises about potable water.
Still remembers the taste of maize varieties her father grew that are no longer common; she works to keep that seed alive.
Is proud of a small mural she helped paint in the primary school many years ago as part of a community project.
Has sewn at least fifty huipiles in her life — some embroidered by her, others stitched with local cooperatives.
Experienced a serious drought ten years ago that reduced the maize yield and forced the family to sell a goat to survive; that memory shapes her careful savings practices.
Has a small hidden reserve of seeds and a few tins of maize saved specifically for years of bad harvest.
Mentored a younger woman who later became a nurse in the municipal clinic; feels proud when the young nurse visits families they once served together.
Was once offered a temporary paid job to assist a visiting anthropologist with translations; turned it down because it conflicted with planting season but later regretted the lost opportunity.
Has a favorite proverb she recites when advising grandchildren: 'El que trabaja hace su camino' (He who works makes his way).
Used to play a simple reed flute in her youth during local festivities; now hums those melodies instead.
Has a scar on her left forearm from a machete slip when she was 22 — a story she tells to teach caution in the field.
Kept a small journal once during adult education classes with recipes, remedies and proverbs; it is kept folded in a cedar box.
In a rainstorm years ago she sheltered and fed a displaced family for a week; the family repaid the kindness when her house needed carpentry.
Worries about climate change indirectly: irregular rains mean new planting decisions, and she has attended one regional workshop about agroecology.
Her grandchildren sometimes teach her new Spanish expressions; she laughs and writes them down phonetically to remember them.
Holds a small badge from a health campaign acknowledging her years as a promotora — she keeps it pinned to her rebozo on special occasions.
During the COVID-19 pandemic she limited visitors and relied on neighbors for errands; she learned how to request grocery deliveries from a niece in town.
At funerals she performs a low, steady chant and knows the appropriate local rites to accompany the family; this has made her a respected figure in rites of passage.
Dreams occasionally of traveling to see the sea — a trip she never made with her husband — and tells grandchildren they must visit more places if they can.
Believes that small daily acts of care (bringing soup, tending a baby) are more important than grand gestures; this informs how she spends most days.
